title-group.article-title: Determinant Factors of the Viscosity of Enteral Formulas
title-group.subtitle: Basic Analysis of Thickened Enteral Formulas

article-meta.aff: 2Kobe City Hospital Organization, Kobe City Medical Center West Hospital, Kobe, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Maki Wakita, Mukogawa Women’s University, 6-46, Ikebiraki, Nishinomiya, 663-8558, Japan; e-mail: amagait@nutrped.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition
permissions.copyright-holder: The American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

abstract.p: Background: Thickened enteral formula (TEF), which is made by adding thickener to enteral formula, has been used mainly in Japan to reduce the incidence of clinical complications associated with enteral nutrition. However, the optimal viscosity of TEF needed to achieve a high efficiency is different for each medical complication and for individual patients. Methods: The viscosity of TEF, which consists of enteral formula and thickener, was determined by 5 factors: (1) formula energy density, (2) formula temperature, (3) stirring speed, (4) stirring time, and (5) time elapsed since preparation. Then, the changing index (CI) was calculated for each of the 5 factors to determine which exerts the most influence on TEF viscosities. Results: The most influential factor (CI ≥−50%) for the decrease in TEF viscosity was formula energy density. In contrast, the most influential factors (CI ≥50%) for the increase in TEF viscosity were stirring time and time elapsed since preparation. Conclusion: The results of this study indicate that formula energy density, stirring time, and time elapsed since preparation are the most influential factors to consider during manipulation of TEF viscosity.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: As mentioned in the American Society for Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition guidelines,1 nutrients should be administered via the enteral route when the gastrointestinal tract is functioning normally.

Although the benefits of enteral nutrition (EN) are often reported, such as maintenance of gastrointestinal morphology and function,2 decrease in the incidence of sepsis,3 and reduction in medical expenditures,4 the complications of EN also must be considered. These include abdominal bloating, diarrhea,5,6 aspiration pneumonia,5 pressure ulcer,7 and hyperglycemia.8 The addition of soluble fiber or polysaccharide thickeners to the enteral formula may help to reduce these complications. In Japan, thickened enteral formula (TEF), made with enteral formula and a soluble fiber or polysaccharide thickeners, is commonly used for this purpose.

TEF, made with enteral formula and thickener, has been used mainly in Japan to reduce these complications. For administration of TEF, a wide internal diameter (ID) of the tube is necessary to prevent tube occlusion. For this reason, TEF is applied mainly for gastrostomy. In general, viscosity is defined as the resistance to flow or the alteration of shape by any substance as a result of molecular cohesion and most frequently is applied to liquids as the resistance of fluid to flow because of a shearing force.9 Some clinical complications that can occur with EN, such as diarrhea and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD),5-8 are observed after administration of a liquid enteral formula. TEF has been reported to be able to prevent these complications.10-13 Furthermore, by using TEF, the length of EN support might be shortened, as well as the immobility periods of patients. These advantages of TEF are expected to prevent pressure ulcer incidence14,15 and could increase rehabilitation time. Although many clinical experiences have been reported,10-15 the most appropriate viscosity of TEF is still to be determined.
In this study, the determinant factors for the viscosity of TEF were evaluated using several parameters, with the amount of added thickener remaining constant.

sec.title: Methods
Enteral Formula and Thickener
sec.p: To prepare TEF for the study, we used ISOCAL RTU (1.0 kcal/mL; Nestle Nutrition, Tokyo, Japan) as the enteral formula and Toromeiku SP (Meiji Dairies Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) as the thickener.

sec.title: Basic Study Conditions
sec.p: Before studying the several factors that influence the viscosity of TEF, some basic study conditions were set as follows: (1) the enteral formula was kept in an incubator for 6 hours at 25°C, which is equal to the hospital temperature in Japan; (2) thickener was added to the enteral formula to prepare TEF; (3) the TEF was stirred using a stirring machine (Bamix; Cherry Terrace, Inc, Tokyo, Japan) at a stirring speed of 12,000 rpm for 10 seconds; (4) TEF was stabilized for 5 minutes; and (5) the static viscosity of TEF was measured by the TV-22 rotational viscometer (Toki Sangyo Co Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; rotor: 13°4′ × R24, speed: 0.5 rpm), E-type rotator for 30 seconds (Figure 1). TEF viscosity was measured 5 times, with results expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD).

caption.p: Basic study conditions. Enteral formula used was ISOCAL RTU. Thickener used was Toromeiku SP. A viscometer TV-22, E-type rotator (rotor: 13°4′ × R24, speed: 0.5 rpm) was used. TEF, thickened enteral formula. Italics indicates the changing conditions in this study, shown in methods 2–6.

sec.title: Method 1: Reaching a Viscosity of 1, 5, 10, or 20 Pa·s
sec.p: The thickeners were added to the enteral formula every 1 w/v%, starting from 1%, until viscosity reached 20 Pa·s (Figure 2). TEF viscosity was adjusted at 1, 5, 10, or 20 Pa·s because commercially available TEFs in Japan are within this range.16

caption.p: Methods 1–7. The 1.0-kcal/mL formula used was ISOCAL RTU. The 1.5-kcal/mL formula used was ISOCAL PLUS. The 2.0-kcal/mL formula used was ISOCAL 2K Neo. V0, viscosity under basic condition; V1, viscosity under changing conditions of formula energy density, formula temperature, stirring speed, stirring time, and time elapsed since preparation.

sec.title: Method 2: Effects of Formula Energy Density on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: To observe the effect of formula energy density on TEF viscosity, we changed the formula from 1.0 kcal/mL (ISOCAL RTU) to 1.5 kcal/mL (ISOCAL PLUS) or 2.0 kcal/mL (ISOCAL 2K Neo). This was repeated for the 4 viscosities (1, 5, 10, 20 Pa·s; Figure 2).

sec.title: Method 3: Effects of Formula Temperature on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: To examine the effect of formula temperature on TEF viscosity, we varied the temperature between 21°C, 23°C, 25°C, 27°C, and 29°C. This was repeated for the 4 viscosities (1, 5, 10, 20 Pa·s; Figure 2).

sec.title: Method 4: Effects of Stirring Speed on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: To examine the effect of stirring speed on TEF viscosity, we changed rotational frequencies from 12,000 rpm to 17,000 rpm, and this was repeated for the 4 viscosities (1, 5, 10, 20 Pa·s; Figure 2). Rotational frequencies were set at 12,000 and 17,000 rpm because of the limitations of the stirring machine (Bamix).

sec.title: Method 5: Effects of Stirring Time on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: To examine the effect of stirring time on TEF viscosity, we stirred TEF for different lengths of time (10, 20, and 30 seconds), and this was repeated for the 4 viscosities (1, 5, 10, 20 Pa·s; Figure 2).

sec.title: Methods 6: Effects of Time Elapsed Since Preparation of TEF Viscosity
sec.p: To examine the effect of time elapsed since preparation, we observed viscosity every 5 minutes for a maximum of 30 minutes after preparing TEF. This was repeated for the 4 viscosities (1, 5, 10, 20 Pa·s; Figure 2).

sec.title: Method 7: Changing Index of TEF Viscosity
sec.p: The changing index (CI) is defined as [(V1 – V0)/V0] × 100 (%), where V0 represents viscosity under basic conditions, and V1 represents viscosity under changed conditions according to the conditions investigated: formula energy density (method 2), formula temperature (method 3), stirring speed (method 4), stirring time (method 5), and time elapsed since preparation (method 6). Therefore, the CI of TEF viscosity was calculated to determine which factor in methods 2–6 was the most influential for TEF viscosity (Figure 2).

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: To determine differences between 2 groups, we used the unpaired t test. To determine the differences between 3 or more groups, we analyzed data by 1-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and then analyzed the Bonferroni methods. Differences in viscosity for methods 1 and 6 were determined using the Tukey method. Differences of P < .05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
Result 1: Reaching a Viscosity of 1, 5, 10, or 20 Pa·s
sec.p: TEF viscosity was gradually increased by varying the amount of thickener added to the enteral formula (Figure 3). When the concentration of the thickener reached 2%, 3.5%, 5%, and 6%, viscosity of 1 Pa·s (1.47 ± 0.04 Pa·s), 5 Pa·s (3.57 ± 0.35 Pa·s), 10 Pa·s (11.11 ± 0.87 Pa·s), and 20 Pa·s (17.73 ± 2.40 Pa·s), respectively, was achieved (Figure 3).

caption.p: The effects of the amount of thickener on thickened enteral formula (TEF) viscosity (result 1). Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. aP < .05 (vs 1%). bP < .05 (vs 2%). cP < .05 (vs 3%). dP < .05 (vs 4%). eP < .05 (vs 5%). fP < .05 (vs 6%).

sec.title: Result 2: Effects of Formula Energy Density on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: At each of the varying concentrations of thickener examined in this study, significant differences were observed between viscosities at a formula energy density of 1.0 kcal/mL and 1.5 kcal/mL (P < .01), as well as between viscosities at 1.0 kcal/mL and 2.0 kcal/mL (P < .01) (Figure 4).

caption.p: The effects of formula energy density on thickened enteral formula (TEF) viscosity (result 2). Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. aP < .01 (vs 1.5 kcal/mL). bP < .01 (vs 2.0 kcal/mL).

sec.title: Result 3: Effects of Formula Temperature on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: When the concentration of the thickener was set at 2%, the TEF viscosity did not differ significantly with changes in the enteral formula temperature (Figure 5). However, when it was set at 3.5%, significant differences were observed between TEF viscosities at 21°C and 27°C (P < .05) (Figure 5). When the concentration was set at 5%, significant differences appeared between viscosities at 21°C and 29°C (P < .05) (Figure 5). Similarly, at 6% concentration, significant differences between viscosities were observed at 21°C and 25°C, as well as between those at 23°C and 25°C (P < .05) (Figure 5).

caption.p: The effect of formula temperature on thickened enteral formula (TEF) viscosity (result 3). The line with circles represents changes in TEF viscosity with 2% thickener concentration, the line with triangles represents the changes with 3.5% thickener concentration, the line with squares represents the changes with 5% thickener concentration, and the line with diamonds represents the changes with 6% thickener concentration. Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. aP < .05 (vs 21°C). bP < .05 (vs 23°C).

sec.title: Result 4: Effects of Stirring Speed on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: TEF viscosity was significantly different at stirring speeds of 12,000 rpm and 17,000 rpm at a 2% thickener concentration (Figure 6). However, at 3.5%, 5%, and 6% concentration, there were no significant differences between TEF viscosities at the 2 different rotational frequencies (Figure 6).

caption.p: The effects of stirring speed on thickened enteral formula (TEF) viscosity (result 4). Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. aP < .05 (vs 12,000 rpm).

sec.title: Result 5: Effects of Stirring Time on TEF Viscosity
sec.p: The viscosity of TEF was significantly increased in accordance with the length of stirring time, except at 10 and 20 seconds with 6% thickener concentration (Figure 7).

caption.p: The effects of stirring time on thickened enteral formula (TEF) viscosity (result 5). Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. aP < .01 (vs 10 seconds). bP < .01 (vs 20 seconds).

sec.title: Result 6: Effects of Time Elapsed Since Preparation of TEF Viscosity
sec.p: After stabilizing TEF for 5 minutes, viscosity was observed every 5 minutes for 30 minutes. As shown in Figure 8, the TEF viscosity was significantly different at the 4 different thickener concentrations. With 2% thickener concentration, a significant difference was observed between viscosities at all time intervals up to 30 minutes. The same phenomenon was observed for 3.5% (up to 25 minutes), 5% (up to 20 minutes), and 6% (up to 15 minutes) thickener concentration (Figure 8). This result suggests that the higher the thickener concentration of TEF is, the earlier the viscosity is stabilized.

caption.p: The effects of time elapsed since preparation on thickened enteral formula (TEF) viscosity (result 6). The line with circles represents 2% thickener concentration, the line with triangles represents 3.5% thickener concentration, the line with squares represents 5% thickener concentration, and the line with diamonds represents 6% thickener concentration. Data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. *After leaving TEF for 5 minutes. aP < .05 (vs 30 seconds). bP < .05 (vs 5 minutes). cP < .05 (vs 10 minutes). dP < .05 (vs 15 minutes). eP < .05 (vs 20 minutes). fP < .05 (vs 25 minutes).

sec.title: Result 7: CI of TEF Viscosity
sec.p: From the CI results obtained in method 7, the following factors were observed to be influential on TEF viscosity: formula energy density, stirring time, and time elapsed since preparation (Table 1).

fn.p: Changing index (CI; %) was calculated as [(V1 – V0)/V0] × 100. V0, viscosity under basic conditions; V1, viscosity under changing conditions of formula density, formula temperature, stirring speed, stirring time, and time elapsed since preparation. Italics represents CI > ±50%.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: TEF viscosity can be gradually increased with the amount of added thickener (Figure 3). Thus, the factors contributing to TEF viscosity were examined with the amount of added thickener remaining constant. By setting the CI in method 7, the influential factors can be categorized into 2 different categories.

The first category of factors is represented by stirring time and time elapsed since preparation, both of which increased TEF viscosity. Therefore, it may be concluded that these factors increase TEF viscosity.

The second category is represented by formula energy density, which decreased TEF viscosity. Therefore, it may be concluded that formula energy density decreases TEF viscosity. As shown in Table 2, it seems that some particular clinical complications with EN might be prevented using TEF with a proper viscosity. However, as proven in Figure 4, the viscosity of a high energy density formula was less than half of the viscosity of the 1.0-kcal/mL formula. In the clinical setting, a high energy density formula is often chosen in patients treated with fluid restriction for chronic heart failure or chronic kidney disease. For this reason, medical staff must be reminded of the phenomenon of viscosity changes when they prepare TEF.

caption.p: Effectiveness of the Thickened Enteral Formula in a Clinical Setting

sec.p: We can therefore conclude the following on the basis of our results. (1) TEF viscosity was significantly decreased with a high energy density formula of 1.5 and 2.0 kcal/mL (Figure 4). A lower energy density formula, such as ISOCAL RTU, has a larger amount of water compared to a high-energy formula with the same volume (Table 3). This water content could explain the thickener’s effect. (2) TEF viscosity significantly increased with stirring time and time elapsed since preparation. This seems reasonable because when stirring time and the time elapsed since preparations are longer, the thickeners are able to absorb more water.

caption.p: Components of ISOCAL RTU, PLUS, and 2K Neo

sec.p: The phenomenon whereby the viscosity was decreased in the high-density formula may be explained by the mechanism of action of the thickener. The thickeners used in this study included polysaccharide thickeners, such as guar gum and xanthan gum. Guar gum is a galactomannan, obtained from the endosperm of a leguminous plant, Cyamopsis tetragonolobus. The main chain of guar gum is β-mannan, which is linearly connected to mannose by β-1,4 linkage, and the side chain has galactose connected by α-1,4 linkage. The mannose/galactose ratio of guar gum is approximately 2:1.

Xanthan gum is a polysaccharide produced by the microorganism Xanthomonas campestris. The main chain of xanthan gum is glucose, which is connected by β-1,4 linkage, and the side chain comprises D-mannose, D-glucuronic acid, and D-mannose, which is connected to the main chain.

These polysaccharide thickeners were hydrated and bound with a water molecule, resulting in an increase in viscosity. As molecules of guar gum or xanthan gum contained in thickeners bind to water molecules to increase viscosity of formula, a smaller amount of water contained in the enteral formula results in smaller amounts of thickener molecules and a decrease in the viscosity of the formula. Several thickeners, which contain pectin, increase the viscosity. Pectin gels by binding divalent metal cations such as calcium. Therefore, pectin gelation ability depends on calcium concentration.
The effects of temperature on the viscosity changes between 21°C and 29°C were observed (Figure 5). The reason for these changes in viscosity observed must be explained in a further study.

From the perspective of clinical application of TEF, some complications may be observed with a liquid enteral formula, such as diarrhea and GERD.5-8 To prevent these complications, it is common in Japan to administer TEF as a treatment for various clinical pathologies. Some of the benefits of thickened enteral formulas would be due to the soluble fiber content. However, the factors preventing these complications are not clear, and the details of these factors must be addressed in further studies.

Furthermore, the definition of TEF and the methods to obtain an optimal viscosity of TEF are not standardized to date. Previous studies on TEF have demonstrated that effective viscosity varies widely from 0.9 to 20 Pa·s11-15 (Table 2). Therefore, the optimal TEF viscosity is different for different complications and for different individuals. For TEF to be clinically effective, it is necessary to manipulate it to achieve the most appropriate viscosity for a particular complication. However, as shown in the present study, TEF viscosity can be changed by varying the formula energy density and stirring time, as well as time elapsed since preparation. The influential factors discussed in this study must be clear for TEF viscosity to be standardized. However, in reports collected for analysis of clinical efficiency, stirring time was discussed in only 3 studies, and time elapsed since preparation was discussed in only 2 of 7 studies, whereas formula energy density was reported in 6 studies (Table 4). Therefore, standardization of the optimal viscosity of TEF for the treatment of complications associated with EN is difficult.

caption.p: Measurement Conditions of the Thickened Enteral Formula

sec.p: To summarize, TEF viscosity apparently can be varied by adjusting 3 factors: formula energy density, stirring time, and time elapsed since preparation. To achieve the clinical effects of TEF, one must manipulate the most appropriate viscosity to prevent complications. For this reason, medical staff who prepare TEF, such as nurses, need to know the determinant factors of TEF viscosity observed in this study. To our knowledge, this is the first report to study the determinants of TEF viscosity.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results of this study indicate that TEF viscosity can be influenced by 3 factors: formula energy density, stirring time, and time elapsed since preparation.
